abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column examines unanimous vote by New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission to grant landmark status to Greenwich Village bar Stonewall Inn; cautions decision to preserve historic site, known for its role in national gay rights movement, is not a guarantee of full salvation; while structure can no longer be significantly modified, owner of building is not prohibited from leasing it in future to a different tenant, including a retail chain.
lead_paragraph: As the home to a turning point in the gay-rights movement, the Stonewall Inn, is made a city landmark, the preservation movement makes a shift to consider New York buildings that resonate culturally, if not architecturally.

headline.main: As a Landmark, Stonewall Gets C– for Looks but A for Meaning

snippet: As the home to a turning point in the gay-rights movement, the Stonewall Inn, is made a city landmark, the preservation movement makes a shift to consider New York buildings that resonate culturally, if not architecturally.
